text: Number Theory and Combinatorics A Problem Set 1. Let n be any natural number and suppose that p1 < p2 < · · · < pn are n distinct prime numbers, with p1 = 2. Prove that p1p2 . . . pn + 1 can never be a perfect square. 2. Find all primes p such that p2 + 11 has exactly 6 diﬀerent divisors (positive), including 1 and itself. 3. Let n be any natural number. Suppose that d is the gcd of n2 + 20 and (n + 1) 2 + 20. Show that d must be a divisor of 81. 4. Find all 4-digit perfect squares whose ﬁrst two digits are equal and the last two digits are also equal. 5. Find all positive integers N such that N (N − 101) is a perfect square. 6. Suppose m is the product of k distinct prime numbers. Prove that for any natural number n < m, the number n(m − n) can not be divisible by m. 7. Prove that any natural number n ≥ 12 can be written as the sum of two composite numbers. 8. Find all positive integers n such that 5 n + 1 is divisible by 7. 9. For any n ∈ N, let S(n) denote the sum of the digits of n (in base 10). Show that for every n ∈ N, 9 | n − S(n). 10. Suppose that a natural number m is obtained by rearranging the digits of another natural number n. Show that m − n must be divisible by 9. 11. Suppose for some positive integers r and s, 2 r is obtained by rearranging the digits of 2 s in decimal expansion. Prove that r = s. 12. When (a + b)(e + f )(i + j)(o + p)(u + v) is expanded, how many terms will be there? Among them how many terms have at least two vowels? 13. There are 8 CCTV cameras in a shop. Find the number of ON-OFF patterns of the cameras if at least two cameras have to be ON all the times. 14. In a book with page numbers from 1 to 100, some pages are torn oﬀ. The sum of the numbers on the remaining pages is 4949. How many pages are torn oﬀ? 15. Is it possible to write the numbers 17, 18, 19, . . . , 32 in a 4 × 4 grid of unit squares, with one number in each square, such that if the grid is divided into four 2 × 2 sub-grids of unit squares then the product of numbers in each of the sub-grids divisible by 16? 16. How many 6-digit numbers are there having all digits of the same parity (all odd or all even)? 17. In how many ways can one split 2n distinct objects into n pairs? (The ordering of the pairs is immaterial.) 1 18. Find the number of positive integers less than or equal to 1000 that are divisible by 6, 10, or 15. 19. In how many ways can you choose an odd number of objects from a collection of n distinct objects? 20. Find the number of ways in which 8 persons, numbered 1 to 8, can be seated in a round table such that 1 always sits between 2 and 3. 21. Consider all permutations of 1,2,3,4,5. If we list them in increasing order, what will be the 100-th number in that list? Also, ﬁnd the rank of the number 35421 in that list. 22. In how many ways can you select 4 numbers from {1, 2, . . . , n} such that among the chosen numbers, no two are consecutive? (Assume that n ≥ 7.) 23. Find the number of 6-digit natural numbers which have no digit repeated, even digits occurring at even places, odd digits occurring at odd places and are divisible by 4. 24. Find the number of 6-digit natural numbers whose digits are chosen from the set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} and each digit (that appears) appears at least twice. 25. Find the number of ways to select a set of three numbers from the set {1, 2, · · · , 2019} such that they form an Arithmetic Progression. 26. Alice needs to move from (0, 0) to (5, 5), moving either one unit up or one unit to the right at each step. However, she cannot walk from (2, 2) to (2, 3) because a wall is in the way. Find the number of diﬀerent paths for Alice. 27. A cube has each of its faces coloured with a distinct colour. How many distinct sets of colours can you get by capturing a photo of the cube on a camera? Note, the ordering of the colours is not considered here. (Be careful: any set of two/three colours might not be seen together because of their positions in the cube.) 28. Suppose you go to a stationary shop to buy notebooks. If the shop sells notebooks of 5 diﬀerent designs for the cover page and you want to buy 8 notebooks such that no design for the cover pages is missed (i.e. you want to pick at least one of each type), then ﬁnd the number of ways to pick such a desired set of notebooks. Note, here ordering does not matter. 29. Suppose you went to a restaurant with ﬁve friends of yours. After having dinner, you decide to have ice-creams, one ice-cream per person. The menu card shows that the restaurant serves 8 ﬂavours of ice-creams. (a) In how many ways can you select the six ﬂavours to be ordered, such that each one of you get a diﬀerent ﬂavour than others? (b) Suppose that the waiter comes and says that only 3 ﬂavours (out of the 8) are available. In how many ways can you select the six ﬂavours to be ordered, such that no ﬂavour is missed? Note: In this problem, ordering of the ﬂavours should be taken into account. (Imagine that the waiter writes them one by one as an ordered list.) 2 30. Call a positive integer monotonous if it is a one-digit number or its digits, when read from left to right, form either a strictly increasing or a strictly decreasing sequence. For example, 3, 23578, and 987620 are monotonous, but 88, 7434, and 23557 are not. Find the number of monotonous positive integers (of all possible digits). 31. For k ≥ 1, simplify the sum: (n 0 ) + ( n + 1 1 ) + ( n + 2 2 ) + · · · + ( n + k k ). 32. Find the number of integer solutions of the equation x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 = 100 if it is given that xi > i − 1 for each 1 ≤ i ≤ 4. 33. Find the number of 4-tuples (ordered list of 4 numbers) (a, b, c, d) of non-negative integers such that a + b + c + d ≤ 100. 34. In the decimal expansion of n, each digit (except the ﬁrst digit) is greater than the digit to its left. Prove that for any such number n, the sum of the digits of 9n must be 9. 35. Given a positive integer n, let p(n) be the product of the nonzero digits of n. (If n has only one digit, then p(n) is equal to that digit.) Let S = p(1) + p(2) + · · · + p(999). What is the largest prime factor of S? 36. Find all primes p and q such that p divides q2 − 4 and q divides p2 − 1. 37. Find all 4-tuples (a, b, c, d) of natural numbers with a ≤ b ≤ c and a! + b! + c! = 3d. 38. If n is a positive integer such that 2n + 1 and 3n + 1 both are perfect squares then show that (i) n must be divisible by 40, and (ii) 5n + 3 can not be a prime. 39. Let a, b, c ∈ N such that a 2 + b2 = c2 and c − b = 1. Prove that, (i) a must be odd, (ii) b must be divisible by 4, and (iii) ab + ba must be divisible by c. 40. For each n ∈ N deﬁne an = (3 + √5) n + (3 − √ 5)n. Show that, (a) an is an integer for every n ≥ 1. (b) an+1 = 6an − 4an−1 for every n ≥ 2. (c) an is divisible by 2 n for every n ≥ 1. 41. Let a, b, c ∈ N such that, a | b2, b | c2, c | a2. Prove that, abc | (a + b + c)7. 42. Let k be an odd positive integer. Prove that (1 + 2 + · · · + n) | (1 k + 2 k + · · · + n k) for every positive integers n. 43. Find all 6-digit numbers a1a2a3a4a5a6 in which each of the digits 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 appears exactly once and for each 1 ≤ k ≤ 6, the number a1a2a2 . . . ak is divisible by k. 44. Call a positive integer n good if there are n integers, positive or negative, and not necessarily distinct, such that their sum and products are both equal to n. Show that all the integers of the form 4k + 1 and 4l are good. 45. Solve the following system of equations: x + ⌊y⌋ + {z} = 200.0, {x} + y + ⌊z⌋ = 190.1, ⌊x⌋ + {y} + z = 178.8. Here ⌊x⌋ denotes the greatest integer ≤ x, and {x} denotes x − ⌊x⌋. 3 46. Find all natural numbers n such that 1 + ⌊√2n⌋ is a divisor of 2n. 47. For positive integers n and r, ﬁnd the gcd of the following numbers: ( n r ) , ( n + 1 r ) , ( n + 2 r ) , . . . , ( n + r r ) . 48. In a ﬁve-team tournament, each team has to play with every other team exactly once. In each game there are no ties. How many possible results of the games can be such that the tournament neither produces an undefeated team nor a winless team? 49. Determine the number of ways to select 3 distinct integers from the set {1, 2, . . . , 30} such that their sum is divisible by 3. 50. Let a1, a2, . . . , an be n numbers such that each ai is either 1 or −1. If a1a2 + a2a3 + · · · + an−1an + ana1 = 0, then show that n must be a multiple of 4. 51. In how many ways can you ﬁll up an 4 × 5 array of numbers with ±1 such that product of the numbers in each row and each column becomes −1? 52. In how many ways can you ﬁll up an 4 × 4 array of numbers with ±1 such that product of the numbers in each row and each column becomes −1? 53. In how many ways can you colour 6 faces of a dice with 6 diﬀerent colours, using each colour exactly once? 54. In how many ways can a row of 10 squares be each colored either red or green in such a way that no two red squares are adjacent? 55. If 4 n + 2n + 1 is a prime number (n ∈ N) then show that n must be a power of 3. 56. Suppose 32 objects are placed on the circumference of a circle, at equal distances. In how many ways can 3 objects be chosen from among them so that no two of the three chosen objects are adjacent nor diametrically opposite? 57. Consider the smallest number in each of the (n r) subsets (of size r) of S = {1, 2, . . . , n}. Show that the arithmetic mean of the numbers so obtained is n+1 r+1 . 58. Consider an n × n array of numbers aij (standard notation). Suppose each row consists of the n numbers 1, 2, . . . , n in some order and aij = aji for i, j = 1, 2, . . . , n. If n is odd, prove that the numbers a11, a22, . . . ann must be 1, 2, 3, . . . , n in some order. (In terms of matrices, we can restate the problem as follows: If n is odd and A is an n × n symmetric matrix such that each row of A is a permutation of 1, 2, . . . , n, then the diagonal elements must also form a permuation of 1, 2, . . . , n.) 59. Consider a sequence a1, a2, . . . deﬁned as an = 2 n + 3n + 6n − 1, n ≥ 1. Determine all positive integers that are coprime to every term of the sequence. 60. A ten digit number is called interesting if its digits are distinct and is divisible by 11111. Find the number of such interesting numbers. 4
